messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 60 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Rerouting Planar Curves and Disjoint PathsThis work was supported by JSPS KAKENHI Grant Numbers JP18H05291, JP20K11692, JP20K14317, JP20H05793, JP20H05795, JP20K23323, JP21H03397, JP22K17854.

Paper Abstract: Abstract In this paper, we consider a transformation of k𝑘k disjoint paths in a graph. For a graph and a pair of k𝑘k disjoint paths 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} and 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} connecting the same set of terminal pairs, we aim to determine whether 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} can be transformed to 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} by repeatedly replacing one path with another path so that the intermediates are also k𝑘k disjoint paths. The problem is called Disjoint Paths Reconfiguration. We first show that Disjoint Paths Reconfiguration is 𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤\mathsf{PSPACE}-complete even when k=2𝑘2k=2. On the other hand, we prove that, when the graph is embedded on a plane and all paths in 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} and 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} connect the boundaries of two faces, Disjoint Paths Reconfiguration can be solved in polynomial time. The algorithm is based on a topological characterization for rerouting curves on a plane using the algebraic intersection number. We also consider a transformation of disjoint s𝑠s-t𝑡t paths as a variant. We show that the disjoint s𝑠s-t𝑡t paths reconfiguration problem in planar graphs can be determined in polynomial time, while the problem is 𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤𝖯𝖲𝖯𝖠𝖢𝖤\mathsf{PSPACE}-complete in general.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 60 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 60"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Irrelevant vertices for the planar disjoint paths problem",
        "On polynomial-time congestion-free software-defined network updates",
        "Congestion-free rerouting of flows on DAGs",
        "Reconfiguration graphs of shortest paths",
        "Classification of reconfiguration graphs of shortest path graphs with no induced 4-cycles",
        "The complexity of rerouting shortest paths",
        "Rerouting shortest paths in planar graphs",
        "Towards single face shortest vertex-disjoint paths in undirected planar graphs",
        "On approximating node-disjoint paths in grids",
        "Improved approximation for node-disjoint paths in planar graphs",
        "New hardness results for routing on disjoint paths",
        "The bandwidth problem and operations on graphs",
        "Shortest vertex-disjoint two-face paths in planar graphs",
        "The planar directed k𝑘k-vertex-disjoint paths problem is fixed-parameter tractable",
        "Shortest k𝑘k-disjoint paths via determinants",
        "A faster algorithm for maximum flow in directed planar graphs with vertex capacities",
        "Shortest non-crossing walks in the plane",
        "A primer on mapping class groups, volume 49 of Princeton Mathematical Series",
        "Maximal flow through a network",
        "The directed subgraph homeomorphism problem",
        "Packing paths, circuits, and cuts — a survey",
        "Reconfiguring shortest paths in graphs",
        "PSPACE-completeness of sliding-block puzzles and other problems through the nondeterministic constraint logic model of computation",
        "On the complexity of reconfiguration problems",
        "Reconfiguration of maximum-weight b𝑏b-matchings in a graph",
        "Shortest paths between shortest paths",
        "Maximum flow in directed planar graphs with vertex capacities",
        "On the computational complexity of combinatorial problems",
        "Flow in planar graphs with vertex capacities",
        "Max-flow min-cut theorem and faster algorithms in a circular disk failure model",
        "On shortest disjoint paths in planar graphs",
        "Approximating disjoint-path problems using packing integer programs",
        "The complexity of wire-routing and finding minimum area layouts for arbitrary VLSI circuits",
        "The equivalence of theorem proving and the interconnection problem",
        "Induced circuits in planar graphs",
        "Non-interfering network flows",
        "Zur allgemeinen Kurventheorie",
        "Introduction to reconfiguration",
        "Multicommodity flows in graphs",
        "Multicommodity flows in planar graphs",
        "Improved max-flow min-cut algorithms in a circular disk failure model with application to a road network",
        "k𝑘k-pairs non-crossing shortest paths in a simple polygon",
        "Rooted routing in the plane",
        "Finding disjoint trees in planar graphs in linear time",
        "Graph minors. VI. Disjoint paths across a disc",
        "Graph minors. VII. Disjoint paths on a surface",
        "Graph minors. XIII. The disjoint paths problem",
        "Relationships between nondeterministic and deterministic tape complexities",
        "Finding k𝑘k disjoint paths in a directed planar graph",
        "Disjoint paths in graphs",
        "A polynomial solution to the undirected two paths problem",
        "Finding minimum energy disjoint paths in wireless ad-hoc networks",
        "Algorithms for finding internally disjoint paths in a planar graph",
        "Finding Steiner forests in planar graphs",
        "Algorithms for finding non-crossing paths with minimum total length in plane graphs",
        "2-linked graphs",
        "The complexity of change",
        "Parameterized complexity of graph constraint logic",
        "Max flows in planar graphs with vertex capacities",
        "Reconfiguration in bounded bandwidth and tree-depth"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 60 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Rerouting Planar Curves and Disjoint PathsThis work was supported by JSPS KAKENHI Grant Numbers JP18H05291, JP20K11692, JP20K14317, JP20H05793, JP20H05795, JP20K23323, JP21H03397, JP22K17854., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
